text: - Hi, my name's Sean Salas,

I'm the CEO and co-founder
of Camino Financial.

We're a FinTech platform
pioneering affordable credit
to underbanked microbusinesses.
We use the power of technology and AI

to make sure that that
capital is more accessible
and affordable than anywhere else
where they could find that credit.

I'm the son of an
entrepreneur that immigrated

from Mexico in pursuit
of the American dream.

My mom, she opened over
30 restaurants here
in Southern California called El Mexicano.

It really set the foundation
for that work ethic,
our passion for small business.
And it really enabled me to empathize
with the broader U.S. Latino community
that I don't think I otherwise would have.
We founded Camino Financial in 2014,

and I'm proud to say that
we've deployed over 5,000 loans
aggregating to over $120 million
into underbanked microbusinesses
predominantly in the U.S. Latino market.
AI and the human element is a big factor
of what makes us unique.

When we think about our tech
stack and the foundation,
it really does start with AWS.
And we're really excited about that.
And we're equally excited about

where AWS is taking its
underlying technology
to facilitate the development of AI,
such as with SageMaker for instance,

of being able to add
more bells and whistles
that enable us to focus on our core

and not necessarily
over-focus on the foundation
of that infrastructure.
And it is not only saving a lot of money
that does translate into lower cost loans,
it also enables us to innovate in places

where we think we have a
core competency relative
to anyone else in the U.S.
So what's unique about Camino Financial
is not only the underlying data
that we're collecting on the market,

but it's also what you
make sense of that data

in the form of AI and ML
inference models, that yes,
enable us to underwrite more efficiently
and score them using our Camino score

to influence every vertical
of the credit application

and funding and servicing
and wealth creation process.

And I think that makes
us the most insightful

in deriving insights and
unlocking invaluable potential
of the microbusiness economy.

When I think about success
stories at Camino Financial,
I can't help but think about Juan Reyes
who owns Flaco's Custom Food Trucks.
He is not only an entrepreneur himself
that's growing substantially,

but he is also enabling
other entrepreneurs

within his communities to
start their own businesses.

After his first loan, his
business grew by over 60%.
he was one of those people
that had a limited credit history.

And over the course of
his borrowing experience

with Camino Financial
has been able to increase
his FICO score at over 100 points.

And so that has enabled him
to not only grow his business

but also access lower cost of
capital with Camino Financial.
- [Juan] Hi, my name is Juan.

I'm co-founder of Flaco's
Custom Food Trucks.
We build kitchens inside the trucks
and we build food trailers, food trucks.
So we build their dreams on wheels.
Our motivation to start this project
is my people, my Latin people.

They was looking for new
opportunities to build a business,
and I think the food truck is a great way

to start a new business
because it's not that expensive
as a restaurant.

Camino Financial has impacted
my business in a good way,

because with all the
loans we get from them,
we can get wholesale products

and we can give better
prices to my customers.

- Financial inclusion
was always our North Star

as a solution to addressing
some of the struggles
that we saw our mom experience.

And that really was the seed
that planted Camino Financial.

I think today, yes, we wanna
offer more credit products
to our members that enable them
to build generational wealth.
What I think is even more exciting

is over the course of the
next five to 10 years,

we really wanna offer an
embedded finance solution
into all our members.
Because what we found is that,
in order to unlock your sales,
credit is a big component to that.

And I think this presents
a really unique opportunity

for Camino Financial to
truly create systemic change,
not just in the microbusiness economy,
but how that microbusiness economy unlocks
the broader U.S. economy.
